RADIOLOGY  Final Report

CTA NECK W&W/OC & RECONS  [**2172-10-3**] 11:34 AM

CTA HEAD W&W/O C & RECONS; CTA NECK W&W/OC & RECONS

Reason: trauma - ? carotid canal injury - PLEASE SCAN NECK TOO
Contrast: OPTIRAY

[**Hospital 93**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
40 year old woman s/p ejection from high speed moving car with
SAH and extensive cranial fractures
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
trauma - ? carotid canal injury - PLEASE SCAN NECK TOO
CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST: None.

INDICATION: 40-year-old woman with ejection from a high-speed
motor vehicle accident, subarachnoid hemorrhage and extensive
cranial fractures. Evaluate for carotid canal injury.

TECHNIQUE: CT of the head was performed.

FINDINGS: There is a right frontal ventriculostomy catheter with
the tip in the third ventricle.

The non-contrast head CT again shows diffuse subarachnoid
hemorrhage and extensive cranial fractures as previously
described. Please refer to that report for discussion of these
findings.

On the CTA, there is no significant abnormality of the right
carotid artery within the carotid canal. However, the cavernous
segment of the internal carotid artery does appear slightly
narrowed compared to the right. It also appears slightly
narrowed relative to its middle cerebral artery branch segments.
In addition, at its anterior genu, there is a 2 mm hyperdensity
which may represent a tiny aneurysm. This could also represent a
small area of intramural contrast leakage, which would represent
a dissection. Confirmation of this finding could be obtained by
cerebral angiography. However, flow is present distally into the
middle and anterior cerebral artery branches.

The left internal carotid artery appears normal along its entire
segment. The vertebral arteries appear also normal as does the
basilar artery. The anterior, middle and posterior cerebral
arteries appear unremarkable. This study is somewhat limited due
to a large amount of venous phase contamination.

IMPRESSION: Slight narrowing of the right internal carotid
artery in its cavernous segment. Near the anterior genu, there
is a 2 mm area of contrast which could represent a small
intramural leak versus a small aneurysm. If an intramural leak
is present, this would be consistent with a dissection.
Evaluation with cerebral angiography would be needed to
distinguish these two findings.

The remainder of the intracranial circulation shows no evidence
of dissection or thrombosis.
.
.
CT CHEST W/CONTRAST; CT ABDOMEN W/CONTRAST

Reason: eval for blunt injury, eval t/l/s spine
Field of view: 48 Contrast: OPTIRAY

[**Hospital 93**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
40 year old woman with [**Hospital 8751**] and head injury
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
eval for blunt injury, eval t/l/s spine
CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST: None.

HISTORY: 40-year-old woman status post MVC with severe head
trauma.

TECHNIQUE: Multidetector axial images of the chest, abdomen and
pelvis were obtained with IV contrast. 120 cc Optiray. Coronal
and sagittal reformatted images were obtained.

CT CHEST: The heart, pericardium, and great vessels are within
normal limits. There is no axillary, mediastinal, or hilar
lymphadenopathy. There is bibasilar atelectasis. Emphysematous
changes are noted in the lungs. There is no evidence of
pneumothorax. No pleural or pericardial effusions are
identified.

CT ABDOMEN: The liver, gallbladder, pancreas, spleen, adrenal
glands, kidneys, stomach, and bowel loops are unremarkable.
Nasogastric tube is identified. There is no free air or free
fluid. No mesenteric or retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy is
identified.

CT PELVIS: Foley catheter is inserted in the bladder. The
uterus, adnexa, sigmoid colon, and rectum are unremarkable.
There is no free fluid and no pelvic or inguinal
lymphadenopathy.

BONE WINDOWS: There are no suspicious lytic or sclerotic osseous
lesions. No fractures are identified. The thoracic and lumbar
spine are normal in
appearance and alignment without evidence of fracture or
dislocation.

IMPRESSION: No acute injuries identified in the chest, abdomen,
and pelvis.
.
.
CT C-SPINE W/O CONTRAST  [**2172-10-3**] 12:31 AM

CT C-SPINE W/O CONTRAST

Reason: eval for fx

[**Hospital 93**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
40 year old woman with [**Hospital 8751**] and head injury
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
eval for fx
CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST: None.

HISTORY: 40-year-old woman status post motor vehicle accident
and severe head trauma.

TECHNIQUE: Multidetector axial images of the cervical spine were
obtained without contrast. Coronal and sagittal reformatted
images were obtained.

FINDINGS: There is no evidence of cervical spine fracture or
abnormal alignment of the component vertebrae. Vertebral body
and disc heights are preserved. There are small amounts of
extramedullary blood tracking along the cervical cord. There is
no prevertebral soft tissue swelling. Emphysematous changes are
noted at the lung apices. Endotracheal and orogastric tubes are
noted.

IMPRESSION: No evidence of cervical spine fracture.
Extramedullary blood tracking along the cervical cord is
subarachnoid blood related to the patient's intracranial
hemorrhage.

.
.
CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST  [**2172-10-3**] 12:30 AM

CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST

Reason: eval fx, bleed, mass effect

[**Hospital 93**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
40 year old woman with [**Hospital 8751**] and head injury
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
eval fx, bleed, mass effect
CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST: None.

HISTORY: 40-year-old woman status post MVC with severe head
trauma.

TECHNIQUE: Non-contrast head CT.

FINDINGS: There is diffuse subarachnoid hemorrhage. There is no
mass effect, hydrocephalus, or shift of normally midline
structures. Scattered foci of pneumocephalus are identified.
There are extensive comminuted cranial fractures extending
longitudinally from the right temporal bone, across the sphenoid
through to a left longitudinal temporal bone fracture. The
fractures involve both carotid canals. Blood and air is seen in
the sella. A fracture fragment is seen in the left external and
middle ear canals. There is likely ossicular disruption. A large
amount of blood is seen in the sphenoid and left maxillary
sinuses. A subgaleal hematoma and contusion is noted over the
left posterior parietooccipital region. Note is made of
diastasis of the lambdoid suture on that side.

IMPRESSION:
1. Diffuse subarachnoid hemorrhage.
2. Extensive cranial fractures including extension through both
temporal and sphenoid bones.

.
.
BRAIN SCAN

Reason: 35 YR OLD WOMEN WITH SEVERE HEAD INJURY, LOSS OF CRANIAL
NERVES, EVAL FOR INTERCRANIAL FLOW

RADIOPHARMECEUTICAL DATA:
27.0 mCi Tc-[**Age over 90 **]m Neurolite;
HISTORY: 35 year old woman with severe head injury and loss of
cranial nerves.

FINDINGS:

Following injection of tracer, dynamic flow and static planar
images of the
brain were obtained in multiple projections. Accounting for the
overlying scalp
activity, there is no significant brain activity seen.

IMPRESSION: No significant brain activity.

.
.
CHEST (PORTABLE AP)

Reason: eval for PNA, effusion

[**Hospital 93**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
40 year old woman ejection [**Last Name (LF) 8751**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] death, purulent fluid from
lungs
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
eval for PNA, effusion
AP CHEST 5:59 A.M. [**10-7**]

HISTORY: Ejection [**Month (only) 8751**]. Purulent fluid from the lungs.

IMPRESSION: AP chest compared to [**10-3**]:

Large areas of bibasilar consolidation, increased on the left
than on the right are consistent with a severe pneumonia. Heart
size is normal. Small left pleural effusion may have developed.
No pneumothorax. The left subclavian line projects over the SVC.


Brief Hospital Course:
This patient was admitted under the trauma service on [**2172-10-3**].
Details of the exact sequence of events of her situation are not
known, but it was known she jumped out of a high-speed moving
vehicle as a passenger and sustained an open head injury. In the
hospital, her brain scans showed massive intracranial injuries,
with near-compressed ventricles. She was intubated, paralyzed
and sedated. Her initial CT head showed a diffuse subarachnoid
hemorrhage and a hinge fracture of the base of the skull through
bilateral carotid fossa. An intracranial bolt was placed by the
neurosurgery service.  Her intracranial pressures remained
consistently high, despite various medical management attempts.
Her clinical examination was futile and despite aggressive
medical management, she had a brain herniation and subsequently
became brain dead. With appropriate steps, she underwent organ
donation. She was prounounced dead on [**2172-10-6**] at 1630.

Discharge Medications:
She was prounounced dead on [**2172-10-6**] at 1630.

Discharge Disposition:
Expired

Discharge Diagnosis:
She was prounounced dead on [**2172-10-6**] at 1630.

She was prounounced dead on [**2172-10-6**] at 1630.
